docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The fact that ''much of medicine is art rather than science'' (Week in Review, Sept. 21) doesn't mean that scientific proof of efficacy and safety is unnecessary. So it comes as a surprise to learn that many medical procedures are being done without sufficient testing and scant proof of appropriateness. Additionally, alternative medical practices like chiropractic, acupuncture and kinesiology have little if any scientific proof to separate them from placebo therapy.
docs.abstract: Dr Stephen Z Wolner letter on Sept 21 article on unproven medical treatments (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Stock market indexes finished mixed yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average flirted with 8,000 for the second consecutive session early in the day but quickly retreated. Technology and small company issues again held center stage, as the Nasdaq composite index and the Russell 2000 index each reached another closing high. The Nasdaq gained 7.91 points, closing at 1,697.36, while the Russell index of 2,000 smaller company stocks eked out a 0.44 point gain to close at 449.42, its eighth consecutive new high.

headline.main: Dow Sputters, but Small Stocks March On

docs.abstract: Dow Jones industrial average finishes down 26.77 points at 7,970.06; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gives up 3.50 points, closing at 951.93; Nasdaq composite index gains 7.91 points, closing at 1,697.36, while Russell 200 index gains 0.44 point, to close at record 449.42; chart (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: WILL folic acid turn out to be the latest miracle nutrient, following in a long line of other miracles that never quite lived up to their advance billing? Beta carotene and vitamin C come immediately to mind. Or will folic acid prove to have staying power after the initial rush to buy it? Folic acid, one of the B vitamins, does have more going for it than many other dietary supplements, because clinical trials appear to show that it reduces the risk of two birth defects. The Food and Drug Administration will now require the fortification of certain grains with folic acid and will permit these foods as well as dietary supplements with folic acid to make health claims. Also pumping up the value of folic acid is increasing epidemiological evidence -- though no clinical trials have been performed -- that folic acid may reduce the risk of heart disease and colon cancer.

headline.main: Eating Well; Folic Acid: Pop a Pill, Or Eat The Food?

docs.abstract: Folic acid, one of B vitamins, is hot item among dietary supplements, but it is also plentiful in dried beans and fruits and vegetables in form of folate; one nutrition expert cautions that people should view nutrients such as folic acid as something that is part of a good diet, and not as a single nutrient taken as a pilll (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following in the steps of New York, Connecticut and other states, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed today that New Jersey provide low-cost health care to more than 100,000 uninsured children from low-income families. Using a combination of Federal and state dollars, New Jersey's plan would provide health insurance coverage through managed-care programs for children whose families have incomes up to 200 percent of the Federal poverty level, which is $26,660 a year for a family of three.

headline.main: Whitman Offers a Health Plan For Poor and Uninsured Children

docs.abstract: New Jersey Gov Christine Todd Whitman proposes that New Jersey provide low-cost health care to more than 100,000 uninsured children from low-income families (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Conseco Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Washington National Corporation, an insurer, for $33.25 a share, or $410 million. Conseco, based in Carmel, Ind., is a $31 billion financial-services holding company. Washington National, based in Lincolnshire, Ill., is a provider of life insurance, annuities and specialty health insurance with assets of $2.8 billion. The acquisition and the pending acquisition of the Colonial Penn Life Insurance Company are expected to give Conseco assets of $34 billion and annual premiums and revenue of $8 billion. Washington National's stock edged up 6.25 cents a share, to $32.4375, and Conseco rose 56.25 cents a share, to $47.625.

headline.main: CONSECO IN DEAL FOR AN INSURER, WASHINGTON NATIONAL

docs.abstract: Conseco Inc agrees to acquire Washington National Corp, an insurer, for $410 million (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation will end its partnerships between doctors and hospitals at a cost of $200 million to $300 million over one or two years, the company's chairman and chief executive, Thomas Frist, said today. The partnerships, which give doctors an economic interest in Columbia's hospitals, have come under scrutiny amid a wide-ranging Government investigation of business practices at Columbia/HCA, the largest health care company in the nation.

headline.main: Columbia's Ties to Doctors To Be Severed

docs.lead_paragraph: Enforcement of child support obligations enters a new era on Oct. 1, when the Federal Government will start operating a computerized directory showing every person newly hired by every employer in the country so Federal and state investigators can track down parents who owe money to their children. States will be able to use the directory to locate parents and dun them, typically by securing court orders to employers to deduct child support from wages and salaries.

headline.main: Vast Worker Database to Track Deadbeat Parents

docs.abstract: Federal Government will begin operating on October 1 National Directory of New Hires, computerized directory of all persons hired in US thereafter so Federal and state investigators can track down parents who owe money to children: states will be able to use directory to locate parents and dun them, typically by securing court orders to employers to deduct child support from wages and salaries (M)
